title: For any seven consecutive day period between 9 October 2020 and 15 June 2021, will there be fewer than 50,000 combined total confirmed new cases of COVID-19 in the United States?
preds:
This question could possibly close tomorrow on 12 June 2021 (if the GJO wanted), since the last possible moving 7d window (9 June through 15 June) will have accumulated more than 50k new cases already.
It is notable that Florida, which used to report about 2k new cases per day, appears to be not even included in the latest reports, since there seems to be a major testing breakdown from 06 June 2021. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1201398
50K per week is not possible since right now it is at 13K or around that number per day. With this rate, 50K will be reached in 4-5 days.

50k per week is 7.1k per day.  WHO still reporting around 13k per day.  Can go up and down in a daily basis quite alot, but it has to halve and rates are slightly increasing. So for that to happen in the next week seems a bit difficult.
Going the wrong way now.  Sadly, it ain't gonna happen.

It's over. Preview of today's cases: approx 16,126. Cases are now increasing a bit and moving farther from a trend line than they have since April 14. Even if the decline continues, it can't be steep enough in time for this question. It's been fun, @JonathanMann, @CJH, @cafebedouin, @Okanaganopolis! Thanks for the discussions and for trying to save me from myself. :)
Looks like cases may have leveled off a bit. Also could just be a reporting thing. But does seem less likely after the weekend. -15.

6 June was below the required average (7143)  with 6408 according to worldometers. But it was a sunday, usually by far the lowest number of a week. We would need a miracle to have similar numbers monday-friday this week, and those will be included in the last possible 7-day period for this question.
Going all in.

Florida alone appears to have had approx. 12k new cases in the first six days of June, Texas has had ~9.5k new cases. Given these two states combined represent about 50.5mn citizens or 15% of total population, and their decline in cases has apparently come to a halt recently, it's unlikely the US totals will fall below 50k over any 7d period, since the remainder of the US (48 States and 85% of the population) would have to compensate on average by having an incidence of only one fifth of that in FL/TX. This is certainly the case in some places, but Alabama, Indiana, Louisiana, Missouri, North Carolina, Oregon and Washington have been notable exceptions lately. Not impossible, but statistically highly unlikely.

50,000 new cases per week equates to 7143 new cases per day, or about 21.5 new cases per million population (2.15 new cases per 100k population).  See https://covidactnow.org/?s=1898818 for new cases per 100k population and for the reinfection rates for all 50 states plus DC. Nine of the 25 largest states -- Texas, Florida, Washington, Arizona, Indiana, Missouri, Colorado, Alabama, and Louisiana -- have either a high infection rate (significantly above 2.15 per 100k) or a high reinfection rate, or both.  A reinfection rate above about 0.75 is high for purposes of this question, since we now need new infections to fall very rapidly.  If nine of the larger states have high numbers that are not declining rapidly it's very difficult for other states to fall sufficiently such that total new infections reach the 50k goal.  I'll go back down to 3%.
Going down slightly after thinking about my full probability distribution for a separate question

I still think <50k is possible, but it would be very tight.
Update 6/6: preview of June 6 cases: approx 5285. The next couple days will likely show where this is going, which almost everyone but me is very certain is not <50k. I recognize that I will probably have a terrible Brier score on this, but this is my honest prediction.

1. I expect one thing and the trend drops further.
2. Risk averse forecast. But I still do not expect it to reach the criteria in time after seeing some states picking up more cases consistent with some of the models.
50k per week is 7.1k per day.  Down to 14k per day, but only 10 days to go to halve rate, and that is not the rate of decline seen.  Also end may holiday yet to manifest in cases.
Combined total cases - read the question wrong
It is already 5 June and since trend is already down but have not looked at the numbers (just peeked) but yes

Preview of June 4 cases: approx 17458. The previously linear decline is slowing slightly. Current forecast June 11 for <50k/week by WHO data, assuming WHO cases are a conservative 10% less than jhu cases. I anticipate this date will continue to shift later as time goes on; the outcome will be close, and we might not see <50k in the forecast period.

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC fell to 0.775 on June 1, and has since risen to 0.789.  See https://covidactnow.org/?s=1893813, and find the average of the "Infection Rate" column.  The oscillating pattern with a minimum mid-week and a maximum over the weekend has continued.  But the overall trend since April 20 has been down.  A 6.4% per day decline will have to be sustained to get the number of new infections below 50k/wk by June 15.  That's only a little faster than the current rate of decrease.  The rate could be accelerating downward, but I would note that the holiday weekend caused a glitch in the curve that obscures the trend. It looks like this one may not be decided until the last day.  But only one bad day is required to put this firmly back into the "NO" camp.  I want the answer to be "YES." But having been way more optimistic than the crowd after the vaccines were announced last November, I'm reluctant to bet heavily on YES.  I will increase the odds from 3% to 7%.

Cases dropped by 55,000 in the last week, if the same were to happen over the next week it would be pretty close with 4 days to spare. That's based on Our World in Data though, which looks like it might have different numbers from WHO. But this is looking a lot more plausible than I would have guessed. Going up for now.

A small few quants in this group are rising fast in their bets. I'm gonna "hedge" up from the crowd. however I believe at a certain number, it just won't drop "below". the 50K number Feels too low to be Dropped BELOW but I'm not as smart and will let my gut share the load with my risk mgmt..

I think we'll likely be under 50k/week according to jhu data by around June 10-13, and according to WHO data by around June 9-12. My line predicts WHO data will be under 50k/week by June 8, but I'm allowing a few more days for the decline to slow. We may just squeak in under 50k, but I think it's likely we'll get there before June 15. (I note that the question closes with June 14 data.)
PS I do note that I am perhaps the only one around who is forecasting "yes" so high.

I shouldn't forget that the WHO numbers are lower than other numbers. WHO data for the week ending May 24 are 11.6% lower than JHU data, and 16.0% lower for the week ending May 17. A linear forecast has been holding really well for the 7-day average for the past 50 days, although it's possible that the curve has started to turn. (A few days ago, I was worried that the curve might be turning upward, but that seems not to be happening, at least.) Right now, forecasting a conservative 10% undercount by WHO, the WHO should register fewer than 50k cases/week by June 8; that date may well get pushed out a few days, though.

I think it's gonna be a matter of days or weeks but the trends say no in terms of the question's criteria. My estimate is aided by my analysis on this question that just opened: https://www.gjopen.com/questions/2025-how-many-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-the-us-will-be-reported-for-the-week-ending-3-july-2021. Thank you, GJO.

Moving up to 50:50. As discussed in previous comments, a linear forecast fits the past now 49 days of 7-day average cases/day really well and slightly better than an exponential fit. At some point, the curve will turn towards zero, and it's possible that this turn has started. The holiday weekend has obscured trends, but hopefully we will know better what is going on once we have data from June 2 or 3. I choose to base my guess about where the curve will bend based on the example of Israel; if it occurred here at the same case load as in Israel, adjusted for population, it would be at ~11k cases/day. There are various reasons to think it would be different in the US (e.g., slightly higher vaccination rate in Israel would make Israel's numbers lower; later time in spring would make US numbers lower), but it's a start. We will likely be at ~11k/day by June 5 or 6. If cases continue falling linearly past that point, we'll see 50k/week by around June 9 or 10. But it's also possible that there will be an uptick in cases because fewer people are wearing masks or variants are spreading more. We'll soon know.

The US is probably going to miss the target value of this question by a week or so. Still needs a decline of ~14k/day. The past few weeks the decay averaged 1k/day per day, which with 14 days remaining would indicate success, but we should now start seeing pockets of the US where Covid is already eradicated and pockets where there is still a sufficient distribution to sustain community transmission. This will reduce the rate of decline (also: no idea why the case numbers no longer follow exponential growth/decline models) and probably make us miss the deadline for this question.  Still staying above the crowd
A lot of chaos with testing and reporting because of the holiday weekend, but I am cautiously optimistic.

If the increase of the few days leading up to the holiday weekend were transient, then I think it's likely we'll see <50k cases in the 2nd week of June. Cases reported for yesterday (jhu data) were 52% of cases 1 week before. Cases reported for the day before were 61% of the week before. But with likely reduced testing and reporting over the holiday weekend, it's hard to know what's really going on right now. Plus, we'll likely see a rebound in reported cases on June 1 and possibly a bit on June 2. Hopefully testing and reporting will settle down by June 2 or 3.
Continued declining trend in https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ makes this seem plausible

Maintaining 0%. I feel like stating the obvious this morning: the US won’t fall below 50k/week in June because vaccines don’t protect the unvaccinated. The subset of US citizens who remain unvaccinated correlates strongly to the subset who refuse to wear masks and social distance. COVID rates among this group have not declined at all since January. There is still plenty of (obstinate, selfish, misguided) tinder for the virus to burn through. Here’s an analysis from the Washington Post: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/interactive/2021/covid-rates-unvaccinated-people/?itid=hp_pandemic%20test.

As per my previous comment, we would need to see a pretty steep acceleration in the *rate* of declining cases in order for this question to resolve as true. I created a chart mapping the past trajectory and various outcomes based on a 15%,20%,25%, and 30% rate of decline. I'm expecting the outcome to fall somewhere between the 15% and the 25% projections, but I'll update if any of the weekly numbers along the way resolve higher than expected. Here is the chart: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/master/weekly_covid_cases/weekly_covid_cases.png
I'm using the data from the WHO dashboard linked in the question description: https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us
The decline of the past month and a half may be starting to drift from linear. I'll move to the crowd forecast until it's clear which way things are going.
A two week halving resolves this question positively, but it still seems fairly unlikely.  Going up slightly 12% -> 15%

I think the decline in cases would likely continue to well under 50k/week in the forecast period, except that there may now be a new upturn in cases. Is this due to the spread of variants and/or people not wearing masks indoors?

Florida, Colorado, Michigan and probably some other states (NY, NJ, PA) with a rather large scope of premature reopenings could be crucial.
CDC's idiotic waiver of masking mandate for vaccinated will protract breakthrough infections.
Variants of Concern, B.1.351 and the newly declared VoC B.1.617.2 are still on the table, they are less likely to be inhibited by at least some vaccines, and will thus protract breakthrough infections and new outbreaks.
A dozen of states still have a test positivity rate of >5%
Two dozens of states still have a high or very high level of community transmission.
And, with the relatively low positity rates in the 75% of  the states, the number of tests currently is inappropriately low compared to what it should be to become aware of outbreaks early, and will be forced up, once severe outbreaks will occur (perhaps in CA next).
In all, the current figures are likely to understate the risk of higher transmission levels; 7-day new cases are unlikely to fall below 70,000 before 01 July 2021, if not longer...

The decline only has to drop by 7.7% and it'll reach target, on average. However, there is still risk about the raw daily counts that is going to be used. I think if we used the average it may be more likely to reach target since it is less noisy than taking the raw daily counts.

@belikewater  You've put a good fear into my thinking. @cafebedouin was strongly on this cause himself and recently stepped back towards No albeit to 25%, still well above the crowd. .  Without much (or any) good science to support my contention, I feel like a certain "bottom" will hit where the linear ramp-down just doesn't get to 50/k week... I assume testing remains abundant as ever
I presume imperfect roll-out of vaccinations will remain as an intransigent issue.
vaccine hesitancy
breakouts here and there... that said, I now think it will be closer than I originally thought.  I'll raise my hedge a little after this a little above the crowd and watch... cheers
Coming up off the bottom slightly...

Decreasing slightly for passage of time. Weekly cases would need to decline by closer to ~40% per week for this question to resolve as a 'Yes'. Seems unlikely given the weekly declines have been roughly half of that (i.e., ~20%) the past few weeks, but exponential dynamics are tricky. We will likely see an acceleration in declines as vaccinations continue to tick up, but unclear if it will happen quickly enough to impact this question.
Going up slightly; exponential dynamics are difficult
New infections are going down fast, just not fast enough to reach 50k/wk.  Reducing odds from 7% to 3%.
ticking up again as the numbers are trending toward the optimistic side of my projections.

I tried to use this https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/ to estimate where it would be. It seems that around closing time, the 7-day moving average of daily cases in the US will be about half its value now—not enough to get to the resolution criteria, I suppose.

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has fallen to 0.85, which is about where it was two months ago.  If it had stayed down this question would already be over.  Instead it rose to 1.05 in early April.  With only four weeks left until June 15 we would need to see a 5% decrease every day for the next month.  It's not impossible, but seems unlikely given the many places where vaccination rates are low.  NJ shows what can happen when herd immunity is approached.  New infections have fallen off a cliff, with Rt = 0.47.  Things could change (again), but if the current trend continues we will reach the 50k/week level before July 4th.  I'll keep the odds at 14 to one for a YES answer.
I'm seeing a close call on the horizon. Keeping tabs on that trend line and wary that numbers vary depending on source.
h/t @yagudin - raising my estimate slightly; there's more uncertainty here than I first thought.

With current nearly linear declines, my lowest forecast for the week is just over 50k.
Update 5/20: Current forecast 57k. Will likely end up slightly higher.

Recent peak was just under half a million 14th April. Need about a 5% drop every day from now to get there. by 15th June. Average has been about -2.36% and only 1 in 30 days has got close. So that would suggest a probability much less than 3%. Have seen things becomes more vertical drop wise in some places (e.g. Israel) with the vaccine, but feels unlikely in the US given vaccine rates seem to be slowing and opening up accelerating. Overall going to go with 5%, probably erring on the side of too high.
Cases are declining quickly right now, and their decline is not currently slowing down.

I agree with @jainsa 's expectation of  approximately 75k-125k per week by June 15th.  # If cases continue declining around 15% per week, that will get us to around 125K.
# If cases start declining faster at 25% per week, that should get us to around 60K.
# If cases decline at 28% or more per week, that would get us to about 47K.
Creeping up again. The US showed a nearly linear decrease from 70k/day on 14 April to 34k/day today. With about the same timeframe left this will come down to weeks.
Expecting the cases to be in the range of 75k-125k per week on 15th June. But still due to the rapid decline the possibility has increased...
seeing a steeper decay than I originally projected.

Up from 0... After a chat with @cafebedouin I'm gonna finish this race a little carefully. I've been well ahead of the crowd on this one, so will buy a touch of last minute insurance through the last stretch till we cross the line.

Vaccine hesitancy means it will be a long time before USA gets cases below 8300 a day. Even if some states do manage to suppress the virus by getting most people vaccinated, there will be outbreaks in states where refusal is high.
Given variants and the aggressive anti vax folks in the US, the probability is lowered.
Daily average is still around 50k let alone for a week.  This has remained quite stable the last few months so unlikely to drop that far by 15 June.
extremely unlikely -- hasn't been that low for a single day, let alone 7 consecutive. with things reopening and herd immunity next to impossible, there is a close to zero chance of this occuring
Given the short window remaining and the current 7-day average about 5x the target rate, these odds are very low.
There is no fear or following of any guidelines for this to happen.

1) vaccine hesitancy
2) as the travel picks up, the number of mandatory tests will pick up and catch higher percentage of actual cases
Case counts will get there, but probably not in time to count for this question.

I guess the only way is a linear trend downward, but the CDC ensemble (and some of the higher performing models on that contribute to the ensemble) project a flattening trend over the next month, which will stall the goal posed in the question.
Dropping. With 6 weeks to go, need a bit over 25% drop a week to get there. Was 25%ish last week I believe so the drop needs to accelerate a bit.

Judging from the small number of updates posted for this question the crowd is very confident of the outcome.  The crowd is almost certainly right, having figured it out way before me.  I was way too optimistic.  But I continue to follow the numbers.  While binary questions have an appealing simplicity, it would be interesting to watch the forecasts evolve for a multi-bin question.  Possible bins: "On or before June 15," "June 16 through July 15," "July 16 through August 15," and "After August 15." The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has fallen to 0.94.  In mid-November 2020 there was a fairly strong correlation (~-0.6) between cumulative per capita infections and the Rt for each state.  Higher cumulative infections correlated to lower reinfection rates.  The speculation was that it was mostly due to behavior, but also possibly to partial herd immunity due to infection.  The magnitude of the January surge settled any questions regarding the cause:  it was due to behavior.  And of course the highly transmissible variant emerged before the vaccine could protect the population.  In any case the correlation completely dissipated by mid-February. Over the past week another strong correlation (-0.6) has emerged, this time between the vaccination rate (1+ dose) and the reinfection rate, Rt, as reported by https://covidactnow.org/.  Vaccinations are clearly having an impact.  The problem, for purposes of this question, is that there isn't sufficient time for states with low vaccination rates to push reinfection rates down.  The five states with the highest vaccination rates are: NH (59.8%), MA (54.7%), CT (53.9%), VT (53.8%), and ME (53.5%).  There are nine states over 50%. The five states with the lowest vaccination rates are: MS (30.7%), AL (32.0%), LA (32.1%), ID (33.6%), and WY (33.6%).  There are seven states below 35%.  With the lagging states having only a little over half the vaccination rates as the highest states it looks like we will see very uneven progress during the month of May.  Some states will have rapidly falling new infection numbers, but some will still have high numbers of new infections.  Progress will be significant, but it will be patchy. So while I believe the progress over the next month will surprise many people, it won't get us to 50k/week by June 15.  I'll keep my forecast at 7%.

Dropping to slightly above the crows as the US vaccination speed peaked in mid April. There is no chance, that the epidemic situation will be well enough in order to sustain <50k cases/7days. The remaining option is a refusal to count new cases, which should not happen within the next 6 weeks. I'm staying above the crowd mainly out of stubbornness, but the chance for a yes resolution is realistically gone

currently still biasing my forecasts toward the crowd to hedge against my earlier estimates which were relatively high. Echoing the comment from my previous forecast, exponential decay in the number of infections is happening in the United States, but it's unlikely to hit less than 50k weekly confirmed new cases before this question expires especially since, as case counts continue to fall, more and more restrictions will begin to lift acting as a countervailing force. Still I think the crowd is a little bit too pessimistic here. My unweighted estimate is probably about 15%.

I'm going to come down a bit, but crowd clearly doesn't understand exponential curves, vaccine rates of 3 million / day and seasonality, all of which makes this much more likely than your linear progression estimates suggest.

exponential decay in the number of infections is happening in the United States, but it's unlikely to hit less than 50k weekly confirmed new cases before this question expires especially since, as case counts continue to fall, more and more restrictions will begin to lift acting as a countervailing force. Still I think the crowd is a little bit too pessimistic here.
Going down from 64K per day back to the pre-pandemic level in only 50 days? No way.

I start to get nervous with me being still very high on this question. Especially since Israel's vaccination effort effectively stalled at 60%. If the US were to experience a similar slow down this would show up towards the end of this question (really the only interesting part though). So far the US is still slightly accelerating its distribution. If the US behaves similar to Israel it should start seeing effects in about a month. For comparison:
Israel's last wave was broken at March 6th with a rate of 55% 1dose-vaccinated, from there it still took a month to reduce the numbers by 10x to below 30/100k/7days. If my math is correct, then 50k/7day corresponds to roughly 150/100k/7day which means slightly more than a reduction by a factor of 15 would be needed.  This all sounds like I'm far too optimistic, but I'm not up for giving up on that hope quite yet
Down after looking at my calibration curves.

time to throw in the towel, I think..
I was always an outlier on this question..
the numbers will drop off the current plateau (rising) as vaccination continues apace.. just not in the time frame of this question.
On reluctance to vaccines, Turkey and India spikes
On Israel improving to 170 cases a day

Chile has vaccinated a larger portion of its population than the US (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=), but they have nearly double the infection rate (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases).  Once they started vaccinating they thought they no longer needed social distancing.  They were wrong, and the US is following their lead.  We in the US are fortunate to have a more effective vaccine, but we are far from herd immunity.  And the clock is running down on this question -- only nine weeks left. At some point fairly soon the new infection numbers should begin to fall sharply, but it's too little and too late.  I was very wrong on this question for quite a long time.  It's going to affect my Brier score, and not in a good way.  Oh well, you win some and you lose some.
Update slightly downwards after looking at my calibration charts.
Everybody please go get vaccinated so we don't have to forecast any more COVID-19 questions.
Going slightly down, seeing as how the aggregate is so confident.

Like @Ruslan-Fazlyev, I'm looking at Israel, where new infections are falling at a rate of nearly 50% per week.  See https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases, and plot Israel on a log scale.  The fall has been steep since about March 10. When the vaccine effect kicks in the numbers should fall very fast.  The problem is  that the numbers are not falling yet, and time is running short.  But I'll increase the odds from 11% to 17%.
Israel is improving fast, updating my forecast.

Going down a bit to the stable numbers right now. I would have expected to observe at least a slight reduction already. Since that didn't happen, I'm backing off a bit. But I still think this should shake out at least very close.

I would be higher without the crowd. Israel needs c 200 a day to be at the equivalent case load and seems to have got there, with c 55% of the population vaccinated and currently I understand almost no restrictions. The US probably needs a bit more vaccinated given a) younger pop in Israel and 2) a lot of the unvaccinated demographics cases may be under reported. But the target is all adults offered first dose by May and that appears relatively achievable. On the negatives:
- vaccine rollout falling far short - seems unlikely, if anything there seems to be more upside to the rollout
- vaccine reluctance - from Israel, Gibraltar etc. It seems like the herd immunity threshold is well below 100%. I can just believe 20% May hold out (although that seems unlikely) but much higher seems very remote
- new variants - not clear that any are entirely vaccine immune and I would expect very high test and trace targets plus shutting down borders Even if all of those are 15% chances - which I think is high for the top two - you get to 65%, so I am definitely allowing the crowd to influence my forecast. What have I missed?

It's the variants (aided by poor policy choices) vs. the vaccines (aided by natural immunity and warmer weather). Which will win?
We might get below a moving 7-day average of 50k cases/day for 7 days in a row (but probably not). But I can't picture a total of <50k cases for 1 week, i.e., 7.1k cases/day avg. Not yet. The US is clearly on a path to allowing every nonvaccinated person to become infected. Update 5/9: For another forecast, I project about 31k cases/day 7-day average on May 15. The 7-day moving average of cases/day has been declining very linearly for over 3 weeks now. If cases continue to decline linearly, we'll be below 0 cases/day on June 15, which isn't possible. Not sure where it will end up, but I can't imagine it'll be as low as 7.1k/day. Update 5/10: Looked at WHO data by weeks. Since the week starting April 12, weekly case totals have declined by 15% to 16% each week. Projecting a 16%/week decline forward, the weekly total for the week ending June 15 would be around 122k to 124k, or 17k to 18k/day.
I'm even more pessimistic than my previous forecast. But 3 months is a lot of time left. So I will remain at 1%.

Between mid-January and mid-February new infections dropped fast.  It must have been due to good behavior and a lack of new, more-transmissive mutations.  Now we seem to have to worst of all worlds -- a nasty B.1.1.7 mutation and a return to risky behavior.  It didn't have to be this way, but I have to be realistic.  It's time to play defense. Does anyone have an opinion as to why CA and TX have low reinfection rates (0.85), while MI is at 1.27 and NJ is at 1.06?  What is going on in Michigan and New Jersey?

With a population of 10M, and 1000 cases a day, Israel is now at 7*1000*40 = 280,000 equivalent. And they are considerably ahead of the US in vaccination and are much more strict on lockdowns. More new strains are getting discovered, too.  So I'll bring this down to 6%, and I'd say if the US even hits the 50k threshold, that's because of lack of testing in some states.

-2 as the decline has flattened out. We're still much closer to the ballpark, but I think there will be enough vaccine hesitancy during the question period to keep cases from dropping that low, though I could see down to 100k cases a week or something like that happening.

I've posted frequently on this question, so if you're tired of me feel free to skip this diatribe. From CDC data [See https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations], 68.8% of the 65+ demographic has now been vaccinated.  Nearly 80% of first shots are now going to people 18 to 64, and the number of total shots given is also increasing.  So from this point on we will be vaccinating the people most likely to spread COVID, whereas previously we vaccinated those most likely to die of COVID. If we track the changes in the CDC data we can see what percentage of the 18-64 demographic is being vaccinated daily.  It's about 0.75%, and this could be expected to increase.  But for a conservative estimate I'll assume it remains constant.  As of today, March 21, just over 20% of the 18-64 age group has received at least one shot.  Linearly projecting this forward gives the following:     Date --------------- Pct 18-64 Vaccinated March 21    ---------------      20%
March 31    ---------------      27.5%
April 30       ---------------        50%
May 31        ---------------        72.5% Forgive the formatting; tabs are not allowed. Vaccine hesitancy will at some point reduce the numbers, and the curve will flatten.  But even if we can only get to 50 or 60%, retransmission should be greatly reduced.  One additional point:  The Pfizer vaccine is authorized for people 16 and older, so this could add an important group (high school students) to the vaccinated population.  See [https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations-process.html.] Time is running short to reach 50k/week by June 15.  And infection rates have not been going down lately.  The average reinfection rate for the 50 states + DC has increased to 0.983.  Rt will have to fall well below 0.90 for new infections to decrease by the 2.3%/day required to reach 50k/wk by June 15.  It's still iffy.  But at some point fairly soon I expect to see the rate of new infections begin to fall as more people are removed from the path of the fast-spreading B.1.1.7 mutation. So I'm increasing the chances (again), from 11% to 23%.  If Rt does not drop significantly by early April I'll join the crowd (again).  If Rt drops in April, to say 0.85, I'll increase the odds for "YES."  That's my 2¢ for today.

March 15th (unconfirmed figures?) 313M cases on weekly basis. 
11st March 98M doses of vaccin administered.

Having lost time to virus denialism, the US has been stuck with a mitigation strategy, i.e., just keep the ICU's functioning.  We put incredible stress on our healthcare professionals so that we could minimize the short-term pain of closing down the economy.  Of course it didn't work, we eventually had to shut down anyway. We succeeded with mitigation, although with over half a million deaths.  So it's not really much of a success.  ICU capacity utilization rates now vary from 27% (WY) to 82% (Georgia). See https://covidactnow.org/?s=1679611.  Having brought down new case numbers we could switch to suppression, but we were and continue to be too divided a nation for that.  Rather than seek to achieve zero infections through test and trace programs we are reducing mask requirements in many states, and opening restaurants to 100% capacity.  And we did this before enough vaccinations could be given to maintain new case numbers on the downslope. Dr Dr. Ashish Jha of Brown University appeared on the PBS newshour yesterday.  See https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/with-states-reopening-widely-new-covid-hotspots-surface.  Dr Jha used a football analogy: we are on the 5 yard line, and we should just hang on to the ball a little longer. Tl;dr: I don't understand the pessimism of the crowd forecast (but I'll happily admit that I'm a bit optimistic). @cafebedouin @Bobbiekar52 @Anneinak @SE_Meyer Currently the US sits at 59k/day [1], so 413k/week, which means slightly more than a factor of 8 reduction is required in the remaining.
The cumulative number of confirmed cases is about 30m [1], which translates to at least 10% [2] immunity based on past infections. We can safely assume that not all cases were confirmed so there should be around 10-25% immunity based on past infections [3].
There are currently 27 doses/100 inhabitants with 17.6 vaccinated/100 inhabitants and a rate of an additional 0.65/100 inhabitants per day [1]. And that rate has (at least approximately) risen by 0.01/day since the beginning of the year [1]. With 14 weeks (98 days) to go this should bring the US to at least: 
  27 + 0.65*98 = 90.7 vaccinations/100 and 
  17.6 + 0.33*98 = 49 vaccinated/100    [*]
assuming statistical independence this gives something like 60% immunity [4], compared to the 25% of now this would reduce the available population by roughly a factor of 2, which would leave a factor of 4 before the question resolves positive.  Now this is a close-to-worst-case assumption. We did not take into account:
- increasing vaccination rate (even if only linearly growing)
- increased cumulative number of infections (even if this is dropping)
- better weather conditions due to the beginning of the summer We can estimate the former two rather easily. Which ends up increasing the average number of daily vaccinations from 0.65 to 1.14 (and the number of vaccinated from 0.33 to 0.57) [5]. This then increases the number of vaccinations per 100 from 90.7 to 138.7 and the number of vaccinated people from 49 to 73.4. Now these are optimistic since I would assume that at 75% completion you start running into problems of a) getting the unwilling to be vaccinated and b) reduced rate since some areas will be done  (and thus drop out of the vaccination resources). But I would assume some positive correlation between "people not willing to get vaccinated" and "people already infected" so that I would assume something on the order of 80% immunity, which in turn corresponds to a reduction of available host population of a factor of 4 (wrt. to the situation now) leaving a factor of 2 that needs to come from the weather/other effects. Counterpoints:
- immune escape due to mutations
- loss of immunity over time
- lack of vaccinations
- increased testing due to freed up resources Of these I really only think the first is a significant unknown. We simply don't know yet how SARS-CoV2 mutates under pressure, but everything we have seen so far is still covered by the major vaccines (or at least claimed to) and only the South African and Brazilian variants seem to have escaped the natural immunity [6]. But even then they lead to significantly reduced symptoms so we might not (have to) care at all. There is no sign of a significant wane of immunity over time (reinfection rates are a few percent) and I don't think we screw up the vaccination production this late into the game. 
The wildcard is the testing, in particular the willingness. I think we will have the situation enough under control to guarantee that the clinic systems will not be overwhelmed again at which point I would assume that the pressure to test will invert and everyone "in charge" will prefer not to test in order to reduce the numbers further. [1] https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-states?country=~USA
[2] slightly less since slightly more the 300m inhabitants, but this is napkin math
[3] https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/
[4] 1 - ( (1-50%) [by vaccination] * (1-25%) [by prior infection] )
[5] (0.65 + (0.65 + 0.01/day * 98 days) / 2) = (0.65 + 1.63) / 2 = 1.14
[6] both are less prevalent in the EU so I could work with outdated/wrong information PS: I was too lazy to find the citations for the reinfection numbers and immunity times, so again: I might work with outdated information, if you are aware of different information please let me know PPS: [*] 0.33=0.5*0.65 persons vaccinated from 0.65 vaccinations

He estimates the first 7 day period we will be below 50k detected cases is around the end of May, with the week before June 15 having a predicted ~21k detected cases.  A few directional things to consider:
• New COVID variant means cases -->
• Vaccine rollout means cases <---
• More people already having COVID (current estimate is 25% of US pop has had it) means cases <-- due to increased population immunity We don't know to what extend the new variant is driving infections currently, but if it is not driving them yet, it's a good bet it will since it is ~55% more transmissible. Also new strains are possible. We know vaccine rollout has been slow so far, but Youyang Gu is modeling for that in his estimates. It's possible more vaccine availability by late spring/early summer could help here too, which he does not account for yet. Finally, he already models for current COVID infection estimates and how that will affect future cases. To summarize, from his baseline, there's one thing I think that may increase spread, one thing that might decrease it, and one thing that is already accounted for. I'll lean towards taking his estimate that cases do fall below 50k/7day a couple weeks before June 15 and give it a 6/10 chance of being true.

So - been doing some thinking / research on this one. Feels like there are a few things to consider - how quickly will the vaccine be rolled out, how rolled out does it need to be for herd immunity, and how does the roll out interact with other public health positions. On the roll out - a few sources: https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-and-biontech-supply-us-100-million-additional-doses Chart halfway through this page: https://time.com/5921360/operation-warp-speed-vaccine-spending/ So - what we seem to know - doses for 100 million people due by 31st July (Pfizer), doses for 100 million people from Moderna (also approved already), not clear on timeline but I am assuming relatively similar timeline, 150 million people from AZ - not approved but seems pretty close to being approved and again presumably a similar timeline (possibly faster as it seems that the AZ vaccine is easier to manufacture?) and then J&J (I understand single dose so 100m) and a couple of others potentially kicking in before the end of Q1 next year. 328m people in the US - feels like to have that many vaccines out there in advance of 15 the June will require a few things, but not everything, to go right - probably needs AZ approved and those 3 providers to go a bit quicker than promised (although I suspect they have been careful not to overpromise) or Johnson and Johnson to come online early next year and roll out fast, or a couple of others to make it and roll out over the course of Q1. On the other hand - feels like being below 40 - 60% needs things to go wrong without anything else going right - still have c70% of the time to 31st July so Moderna and Pfizer alone should get there if everything goes to plan, and even if they have issues, one of the vaccines is less effective/does not work on one variant, problems with logistics of the roll out etc., just AZ should be able to pick up the slack, or one of the others further behind. 60 - 80% roll out - clearly somewhere in between - AZ coming through and all going to plan should get there, AZ coming through but a few issues could be compensated by J&J or another candidate coming through. Pfizer and Moderna over delivering could also get there. Putting some ranges here, let’s say cumulatively:
10 - 20% chance close to 100% vaccinated
40 - 60% that 60 - 80% done
80%+ that 40 - 60% done We do not seem to know what the threshold for Herd immunity is, but wiki thinks it is 60 - 80% covered (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herd_immunity). So let’s say 50% chance herd immunity occurs in the 60-80% threshold and 100% above that and zero chance below 60%. Finally - interaction with other public health measures. This seems quite tricky - Western Europe and US seem to have a pattern where they have r values in the 1.1 - 1.5 range, until cases get unacceptably high, then go through severe restrictions until they get it back to a more acceptable rate. Vaccine in the 40 - 60% range would seem to suggest that restrictions in place currently would take the r rate down to below 1 so should be possible even in the lower vaccination scenarios. However it may be that the benefit is “taken” as more freedom and the US certainly found a run rate well above 50k as “acceptable” in September/October. In addition, we could well have a scenario where the vulnerable people are covered, deaths are low, but we have a high case load as people get back to normal without worrying about spread. On the flip side, Germany had case loads proportionally this low in Sep/Oct, there is a new us administration coming in that seems to want to fight covid hard (albeit, federal system and seperation of powers may limit the ability to do so), it may well be that clever vaccination means that the limits needed to bring down case loads are very “reasonable” (offices closed where wfh works and no “big” events like sports), plus the chance of a positive “perfect storm” where a large effort given current high caseloads, new admin, and vaccine coming through combine towards the end of Q1 to drastically reduce cases. I am putting a big range on the prob here of a non herd immunity drop in cases to this level; 15 - 60%. Taking the lower ends, you get:
25% herd immunity (10% close to 100% vaccinated, 30% 60 - 80% vaccinated and half of that giving herd immunity.
Plus  8% other positive outcomes) (55% good vaccine outcomes but no herd immunity and 15% a “good” outcome.
For 33% total Higher ends you get:
40% herd immunity
36% other positive outcomes
76% overall. Mid point is 55%. Decided to be a bit more conservative at 50% given the lower crowd position and seeming conservative view from Fauci.

The current 7-day average of cases in the U.S. is about ~200,000/day [1]. This amounts to ~1,400,000 total cases in the last seven consecutive day period. Cases falling to a 7-day average of ~7,100 so as to amount to a total of 50,000 total cases in a seven consecutive day period between now and 15 June would mean that the situation at some point in the late spring/early summer would have to have improved so much so as to be just **3.6% of the current case numbers** (50,000/1,400,000 * 100 = 3.6%). Another way to think of this is it would mean **cases have to fall by 96.4% from where they are now**. This seems unlikely to me, especially given the fact that herd immunity through vaccination+cases is unlikely to have been achieved until late summer/early fall [2]. [1] https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us
[2] https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/

Factors for YES: 1) After high risk groups have been vaccinated we can start giving shots to healthy people in "essential jobs" such as meatpacking plants, warehouses, supermarkets, etc.  These workers come in contact with many people, so are more likely to get infected and then to spread the disease.  I'm betting that these folks will want the shot(s).   2) Winter will end, and people will spend more time outside. 3) To get campus life back to normal I would expect vaccination campaigns at colleges and universities to reach most students by April or May.  High school students should also be offered the vaccine. 4) By spring there may be a vaccine available that does not require two doses. 5) Nearly 6% of the US population has already tested positive for COVID.  Somewhere between 10% and 30% have probably developed some immunity.  Among those already infected are the people with the most social contacts who are most likely to have been super spreaders. Factors against: 1) Possible virus mutation -- I rate this an unlikely possibility.  But if I'm wrong my forecast will be a disaster. 2)  After tens of millions of people get vaccinated, new infections could drop significantly.  If this causes complacency, and/or many low-risk people forgo a vaccination, the downward trend could slow.  To reach 50k in one week the rate of new infections must go down without a major interruption. 3) Initial vaccinations won't help much.  Sicker and older people will be saved, and should be first in line.  But the super spreaders are not in this demographic. 4) When there is sufficient vaccine to reach everybody will some people refuse the shots?  How will universities and high schools encourage all students to get vaccinated, and will there be resistance?  How many anti-vaxers are there?  We will find out this spring.

Still not statistically likely.  Unfortunately I do not believe this is even a remote possibility. The U.S. has not seen case numbers this low since the very beginning of the pandemic. To not go over 50,000 cases over a 7 day period, there would be an average of only 7,142.857 cases per day. According to the WHO, or any site tracking COVID, there hasn't been a 7 day average that low since the week of 9 March (or earlier), and the lowest case rate the U.S. has seen since was still at around 20,000 per day. With the dramatic increase we are about to see, I am not sure we can even get back down to 20,000 a day by then without another shutdown, and that seems unlikely considering the backlash from the last shutdown. I do no believe there will be enough vaccines available to make a dent by then either. I read an article recently that compares the vaccine to a fire hose to stop the spread of the virus. A highly effective Vaccine is a very strong fire hose. However, with the extremely high case rate we are seeing, we are taking a strong fire hose to fight the country's worst forest fire ever by comparison. If we had lower case rates, meaning it was just a small fire to put out, it would be a lot easier to see cases go down by then. Before the vaccine can be effective, we would need enough doses to vaccinate the majority of the population at the same time, or we would need a lower case rate and a good rate of vaccinations in areas where the cases are most prevalent. If the time frame were longer, say 15 December, I would have more faith in the vaccine helping to get case numbers that far down. However, our lowest case rate over a 7 day period since 9 March occurred during the week of 25 May, with an average case rate of 20,205 cases per day. The U.S. was nowhere near the case rate it is at now when the downward curve began, since the highest weekly rate was 219,073 in April before going down. We are seeing that many cases per day right now. The average case rate per week since 2 November in the U.S. is 1,047,842 new cases, and this includes the week of 2 November, which had 684,493 new cases according to the WHO. Without that week, the U.S. averaged 1,138,679 new cases per week during the last four weeks, and last week was 1,251,632 new cases in 7 days. It takes weeks to get the case numbers down after a surge that is significantly smaller than what we are seeing now, so who knows how long the current surge will effect us. The worst two months are yet to come, and I do not see it improving so drastically after spring comes that we see case numbers drop to about a third of what they were at our lowest case rate since the beginning of the pandemic. I think 46 million is more certain so let's estimate the number to a weighted average 1/3 - 2/3, giving 77 million in the beginning of December. 50,000 is a very low number. The lowest we've been since April is 150,000 in a week. The big factors making that possible would be immunity due to spread of the virus and immunity due to a vaccine, which I would think would be fairly prevalent by then. Another could be measures taken by a president Biden, such as mask mandates or a more aggressive test and trace program. Factors making it unlikely are low seroprevalence (just briefly googling around it still looks like estimates put the country as a whole as less than 10% having antibodies) and low vaccine usage (some surveys indicate only 50% or so of the population might get it) and just the data we have for spread of the virus in the US to date. I do also wonder if having had one of the worst outbreaks when measured relative to population that we regress to the mean at some point, though lately other countries have been seeing worsening outbreaks which may mean the US isn't just an outlier. A 1 in 10 chance seems appropriate, seems pretty unlikely but lots of unknowns.
